sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: &project; is a GNOME2 project that provides integration of Gnu Privacy Guard (GPG) with the GNOME desktop. &project; includes the &app;, a GPG key management front end, &daemon;, a drop in replacement for gpg-agent as well as a DNS-SD HKP &key; server, and plug-ins for Text Editor and nautilus.
The &app; provides a front end to many of the features of Gnu Privacy Guard (GPG). The contents of this guide concerning the &app; are linked below:

sect1.title: Creating Encryption Keys
sect1.para: There are two methods of creating OpenPGP keys in &app;:the key generation assistant and the advanced generation dialog.

Access the assistant by choosing
Key Create Key Pair
. Select Assistant and press the enter key or press Continue.

Access the advanced generation dialog by choosing
Key Create Key Pair
. Select Advanced and press the enter key or press Continue.

sect2.title: Key Generation Assistant
sect2.para: After following the instructions above, the assistant will walk you through the process of generating a key pair.

sect2.title: Advanced Key Generation
sect2.para: After following the instructions above, you will be presented with a dialog to fill in. The fields are detailed below.

listitem.para: Enter your full name in the form <first> <last> A middle name or initial is optional. You must enter at least 5 characters in this field.
Your email address is how most people will locate your key on a key server or other key provider. Make sure it is correct before continuing. It should be of the form <user name>@<domain name>
The comment field can be used to place any additional information into the displayed name of your new key pair. This information can be searched for on key servers.
This field specifies the encryption algorithms used to generate your keys.
This is the suggested choice as it will allow you to encrypt/decrypt/ sign/verify as needed
Will allow signing only.
Will allow signing only.

This is the length of the key in bits. The longer the key, the more secure it will be, provided a strong passphrase is used. Conversely, performing any operation with a longer key will require more time than it would with a shorter key. Acceptable values are between 1024 and 4096 bits. At least 2048 bits is recommended.

This is the date at which the key will cease to be usable for performing encryption or signing operations. A reasonable time to set it to is 6 months. You will have to either change the expiration date or generate a new key or subkey after this amount of time passes. Sign your new key with your old one before it expires to preserve your trust status.
Use similar practices to generating a strong password when choosing a passphrase. The difference between a password and a pass phrase is that in a passphrase spaces are valid characters.

sect1.title: Importing Keys
sect1.para:
Importing keys can be performed by choosing
Key Import
and selecting a file containing at least one ASCII armored public key in the file chooser. You can also paste keys by selecting an ASCII armored public block of text, copying it to the clipboard and choosing
Edit Paste Keys
.

sect1.title: Exporting Keys
sect1.para:
Exporting keys can be performed by selecting the keys in the main window and choosing
Key Export . You can also export keys to the clipboard, in an ASCII armored block of text, by selecting the keys in the main window and choosing
Edit Copy Keys
.

sect1.title: Backing up Keyrings
sect1.para:
You can back up your public and private keyrings to an archived file by choosing
Key Backup Keyrings
. Enter a file name with a valid archive extenision and specify the location to save the archive. You can choose any of the archive types file-roller supports.

sect1.title: OpenPGP Key Properties
sect1.para: The descriptions in this section apply to all OpenPGP keys

listitem.para: The fingerprint is a unique string of characters that exactly identifies a key

The KeyID is similar to the Fingerprint. However the KeyID only contains the last 8 characters of the fingerprint. Most of the time it is possible to identify a key with only the KeyID, but occasionally two keys may have the same ID.
Specifies the encryption algorithm used to generate a key. DSA keys can only sign. ElGamel keys are used to encrypt.
Indicates the date the key was created.
Indicates the length in bits of a key. In general the longer the key, the more security it provides.A long key is not enough to make up for the use of a weak passphrase.

sect2.title: Trust
sect2.para: Trust is an indication of how sure you are of a person's ability to correctly extend the web of trust. When you are faced with a key you have not signed, the validity of that person's key will be determined based on the signatures they have collected and how well or not you trust the people who have made those signatures. By default, an unknown key will require 3 signatures with marginal trust value or 1 fully trusted signature.

listitem.para: Unknown You are not familiar with the person's ability to sign keys correctly.
Never This person cannot correctly sign keys.
Marginal This person checks for photo ID before signing a key, but does not necessarily scrutinize the IDs.
Full This person scrutinizes each and every person's photo IDs before signing them (e.g. they only sign keys that truely belong to the person asking for the signature).
Ultimate This level of trust should only be assigned to your own keys.

sect2.title: Enabling and Disabling Keys
sect2.para: When a key is enabled, it can be used to perform encryption operations. When a key is disabled, it cannot be used to encrypt to or verify signatures made by it.

sect2.title: Expiration Date
sect2.para: A key can no longer be used to perform key operations after it has expired. Changing a key's expiration date to a point in the future re-enables it. A good general practice would be to have a master key that never expires and multiple subkeys that do and are signed by the master key.

sect2.title: User IDs
sect2.para: User IDs allow multiple identities and email addresses to be used with the same key. They usually take the form of: Name (comment) <email address>.

sect2.title: Photo IDs
sect2.para: Photo IDs allow a key owner to embed one or more pictures of themselves in a key. These identities can be signed just like normal user IDs. A photo ID must be in JPEG format and is recommended to be no larger than 240x288 pixels.

sect1.title: File Manager
sect1.para: &project; offers integration with the GNOME file manager nautilus. Because of this integration, you will be able to encrypt, decrypt, sign and verify files as well as import public keys from the file manager window without launching &app;.

sect2.title: Encrypt Files
sect2.para: To encrypt files, select one or more files in the file manager, right click on any selected file and choose Encrypt from the context menu. You will then be presented with a dialog allowing you to choose the people you would like to encrypt the file to. Select them by marking the check box next to their name. Press OK to finish the process.

sect2.title: Sign Files
sect2.para: To sign files, select one or more files in the file manager, right click on any selected file and choose Sign from the context menu. You will then be asked for your passphrase, if required.

sect2.title: Decrypt Files
sect2.para: To decrypt an encrypted file, double click on the appropriate file. You will then be prompted for your passphrase, if required.

sect2.title: Verify Signatures
sect2.para: To verify files, double click on the the detached signature file.
sect2.note: Detached signature file names often take the form <file name to be verified>.sig

sect1.title: Text Editor
sect1.para:
To enable the &project; plugin in gedit choose
Edit Preferences
. Then select the tab Plugin and check Text Encryption.

sect2.title: Encrypt Text
sect2.para:
To encrypt a selection of text, select the text you want to encrypt and choose
Edit Encrypt
. You will then be presented with a dialog containing a list of recipients. Check the boxes next to the people you want to encrypt text to and press Ok. You can now copy or save the encrypted text.

sect2.title: Sign Text
sect2.para:
To sign a selection of text, select the text you want to sign and choose
Edit Sign
. You will then be prompted for the passphrase to your secret key. After entering your passphrase you will be able copy or save the signed text.

sect2.title: Decrypt/Verify Text
sect2.para:
To Decrypt and or Verify a selection of text, select the text you want to sign and choose
Edit Decrypt/Verify
. If you are decrypting text, you will then be prompted for the passphrase to your secret key. After entering your passphrase you will be able copy or save the decrypted text.

sect1.title: Encryption Preferences
sect1.para:
This section describes the preferences settable with
Desktop Preferences Encryption Preferences from the panel or
Edit Preferences from within &app;.

sect2.title: Key Manager
sect2.para: These options control which columns are visible in the key manager.

sect3.title: Validity
sect3.para: Validity is an indicator of how well you know the key belongs to the person claiming it as their own. Do not mark a key as ultimately valid unless you are 100% sure it belongs to the appropriate person. Validity affects the trustworthiness of a key's signature.

sect3.title: Expires
sect3.para: The date after which a key can no longer be used to encrypt to or be used to make signatures.

sect3.title: Trust
sect3.para: This is the level at which you trust the person to verify the identity of other people when they sign keys and set the validity level correctly and with proper procedures.

sect3.title: Type
sect3.para: Whether the key is an OpenPGP key or a S/MIME certificate.

sect2.title: Encryption Settings
sect2.para: This section describes settings affecting encrypting and signing files.

sect3.title: Encrypt to Self
sect3.para: Sets whether or not you will be added to the recipients list for all files encrypted by &app;.
sect3.note: If you don't select this and you don't select yourself as a recipient you will be unable to decrypt any files you encrypt.

sect3.title: Armor Encode Files
sect3.para: Whether or not files are ASCII armored or not when encrypted. Armoring encrypted files is generally a good idea because some binary files do not always make it through email intact.

sect3.title: Default Signing Key
sect3.para: This is the key that will be used by &app; to sign files. It will also be the key that files will be encrypted to if Encrypt to Self is selected.

sect2.title: Password Cache
sect2.para: Enabling &project;'s passphrase caching ability will allow you to perform many operations that require entering your passphrase without rentering it every time. seahorse-daemon takes the place of gpg-agent. Letting the cached passphrases expire is usually a good idea. This will then require rentering your passphrase, but adds security.

sect2.title: Key Servers
sect2.para: Keep your and other's keys up to date by syncing keys periodically with remote keyservers. Syncing will make sure that you have the latest signatures made on all of your keys so that the web of trust will be the most useful.

sect3.title: Server Types
sect3.para: &project; currently provides support for HKP and LDAP keyservers.

sect4.title: HKP Servers
sect4.para: HKP keyservers are ordinary web based keyservers such as the popular hkp:// pgp.mit.edu:11371; Also accessable at http://pgp.mit.edu.

sect4.title: LDAP Keyservers
sect4.para: LDAP keyservers are less common, but use the standard LDAP protocol to serve keys. ldap://keyserver.pgp.com is a good LDAP server.

sect2.title: Key Sharing
sect2.para: Key Sharing is provided by DNS-SD also known as Bonjour or Rendevous. Enabling key sharing will add the local &app; users' public key rings to the remote search dialog. Using these local "key servers" will most likely be faster than accessing remote servers.
sect2.note: To enable key sharing, you must have started mDNSResponder before seahorse-daemon.
